content.webTitle: Claudio Ranieri: more chance of ET landing than Leicester retaining title

fields.headline: Claudio Ranieri: more chance of ET landing than Leicester retaining title
fields.bodyText: Claudio Ranieri has wasted no time in kickstarting the Premier League mind games by claiming it is more likely that “ET comes to Piccadilly Circus” than his Leicester City side retain their title. Speaking in the buildup to the season’s opening match, the champions’ trip to Hull City on Saturday lunchtime, Ranieri was in characteristically gnomic form, insisting he expects the big clubs to return to form and that his side’s first ambition is to avoid relegation. He also said Riyad Mahrez would be staying, joking that he would kill the Algerian before letting him leave. “I work to be safe,” the manager said in a revival of the mantra he used last season even when his Foxes were top of the league. “I say to my fans: ‘We want to be safe, to build a team, anything more and that’s fantastic.’ It’s not normal that we can win the league. It’s more difficult than last season. It’s easier that ET comes to Piccadilly Circus.” Ranieri continued in the same vein by insisting bookmakers should price his side at even longer odds for the title than the now famous 5,000-1 offered this time last year. But the 64-year-old also had words for his rivals before the season kicks off. “I think the bookies have to pay 6,000-1 now,” he said. “We are ready to defend our title but we know it is a different gap. The big teams will be back, I am sure. They can’t make the same mistake for another year. They lost one season in the life of a big team. There are five, six teams who can win it this year. It will be a good fight.” The former Chelsea manager pointed to last weekend’s Community Shield, in which Leicester lost 2-1 to Manchester United, as an example of the gulf between his club and more familiar title challengers. “I believe big clubs have more quality, more than us, but we are a team,” he said. “Look, on Sunday we lost a match. We were a team but Ibrahimovic was there and we lost. I want our players to fight and to show their best qualities. Then, if there is a champion who can invent something, what can we do? This is why I say the other teams are fantastic champions who cost a lot of money but we have to stay a team.” One of the players whose quality decided the league in Leicester’s favour last season was Mahrez. He has been the subject of constant transfer speculation this summer but Ranieri continued to talk tough over the winger. “Could you tell me who is interested in him?” he asked when the subject was raised. “No, not Arsenal. We’ve had no bids. I think it’s not a problem. It’s a process to improve his career. The Champions League is very different to the Premier League and he can improve with us. Riyad stays with us. Never never never has he come to me and said ‘I want to go’ because I’d kill him before he does.” At this point Ranieri mimicked choking an insubordinate Mahrez. “He’s a lucky man,” he said. While Ranieri seeks to lower expectations on his outperforming squad, he is also setting new plans in place. He has spent £40m in the transfer window recruiting, among others, the defensive midfielder Nampalys Mendy and the pacey Nigerian striker Ahmed Musa, a player he likened to Jamie Vardy. “It’s important to have another player who can play in a similar way to Jamie,” Ranieri said of Musa. “He can play in a similar way but also together with Jamie. It’s important to have good options so I can choose the XI, but also so that during the match I can read it and think: ‘Oh, I need this kind of player with this quality.’ “To have pace in the side is not my only priority. I want to play well, to score a goal, not concede a goal, have a good balance on the pitch, lots of things. Of course if you have a good player with lots of pace it’s a good thing but other teams have that too. It’s a different league that the new signings are coming from. They have to understand the Premier League. I hope they understand very soon.” Ranieri admits he will need a Plan B to outwit opposition who come to the King Power Stadium with the sole intention of going home with a point: “It could be that I change something in the team.” He will also, however, have to deal with the demands of at least six midweek Champions League games. “I hope we are ready. I want to make a good experience in the Champions League,” he said. “If it’s not possible to make the knockout stages, we want to make the Europa League … It will be a good experience and we will get a lot of good mental energy. We are not used to the routine of Champions League and Premier League, Champions League and Premier League, and in the beginning when you are not used to it, you lose a little more in the league. That’s why I am curious to see how it goes. It’s not easy to play in four competitions.” Those competitions begin on Saturday. Hull are newly promoted and without a manager after the resignation of Steve Bruce but Ranieri wryly observed his next opponents were not to be taken lightly. “Be careful with people when they’re favourites for relegation,” he said.
